problemStatement.plain: Prove that the Collatz sequence reaches 1 for powers of 2 (trivially by halving) and for other structured starting values. Includes closure property: if n reaches 1, so does 2n.

proven: If n reaches 1, then 2^m * n reaches 1
knownResults.goal: Prove termination for structured starting values

currentState.focus: Completed - powers of 2 and closure properties

knowledge.progressSummary: Proved Collatz reaches 1 for powers of 2 by induction (each step halves). Proved closure under multiplication by 2. Verified computationally for 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, and famous case n=27 (111 steps).

builtItems.name: ReachesOne
builtItems.description: Exists k such that collatzIter k n = 1

insights: Function.iterate_succ_apply: f^[n+1] x = f^[n] (f x) - puts new step at end
Powers of 2 proof: induction where each step peels off one halving
Pattern 2^n - 1 is harder - doesn't simplify nicely after 3n+1
nextSteps: Consider Merkle-style analysis of stopping times

approaches.name: Induction on iteration
approaches.hypothesis: Can prove termination for powers of 2 by induction
approaches.strategy: Show 2^k halves k times to reach 1
